title: About
text:
Here are my core principles which guide my work and life:

Useful. If it’s not useful, then what’s the point?
Clear. I loathe unnecessary complexity,
Respectful. We don’t all share the same values, and beliefs. That’s a good thing.
Resourceful. Wasted resources here could have been used elsewhere.
Humble. I’ve been wrong before, and I’ll be wrong again.

title: About
text:
Rolling list of interests

[Nov 2024] I’m pretty into anything cyberpunk / synthwave these days. Especially Gunship. For that reason I updated this site to use the “Cyberpunk aesthetic” vapor theme. I’m sure I’ll change it to something more basic when the novelty wears off.

[Nov 12, 2024] It wore off.

title: Experience
text: This page contains an overview of my Education, Work Experience, Presentations and Videos, Publications, and Open Source projects:

title: Experience
text:
Education
I have a diverse educational background that has shaped my approach to data science and decision making. I am grateful for the opportunities I have had to learn from some of the best in the field.
I have a PhD in Cognitive Psychology from the University of Basel and the Max Planck Institute for Human Development. I have an MS in Quantitative Psychology from Ohio University and a BA in Mathematics from Grinnell College.

title: Experience
text:
Work Experience
Here is a selection of my work experience. See my LinkedIn page for a more detailed history.
Most recently, I was the CTO and Co-Founder of Plinth Analytics, a company that helps healthcare organizations make better decisions with messy healthcare data. In this role, I led the development of our data science platform and worked with our customers to understand their needs and deliver solutions that helped reduce costs and generate new use-cases.
I am currently a Quantitative Scientist at Flatiron Health, where I work on real-world data science problems in oncology.

CTO, Co-Founder, Plinth Analytics

The thrill of a lifetime with my co-founder and friend Kieran Mace, along with rockstar data scientists Nicole Mirea, Parker Barnes |

Quantitative Scientist, Flatiron Health

Best culture and teams I’ve ever been a part of. Grateful to people like Olivier Humblet, Caleb Jordan, Daniel Obeng, Conal Scanlon, John Zielinksi (and so many more) for teaching and supporting me during my time there.|

Real World Data Scientist, Roche

Where I learned how real world science is done by teams and what a great manager looks like (thank you Robert Walls)

Postdoctoral Researcher, University of Basel
Postdoctoral Researcher, University of Konstanz

Developing FFTrees with Hansjoerg Neth and Wolfgang Gaissmaier was a turning point for the rest of my career

Pre-Doctoral Researcher, Max Planck Institute for Human Development

Paradise for decision-making research thanks to Gerd Gigerenzer, Ralph Hertwig and where I discovered a love of R with my fellow PhD student Dirk Wulff|

title: Experience
text:
Presentations and Videos
Here are some presentations and recordings of me speaking at various conferences, as well as some teaching course materials.







FlatironKitchen: How we overhauled a Frankensteinian SQL workflow with the Tidyverse| RStudio Conf (2019)|
FFTrees: An R package to create, visualise and use fast and frugal decision trees useR! (2017)|
Using R to Derive Robust Insights from Real-World Health Care Data | R/Pharma (2022) |
TStat R Lecture #7: Loops in R | Introduction to R Programming course at the University of Konstanz (see all course videos here)|

title: Experience
text:
Publications
Here are the two publications I’m most proud of, see all of them at Google Scholar

FFTrees: A toolbox to create, visualize, and evaluate fast-and-frugal decision trees, Phillips, N.D., Neth, H., Woike, J.K., Gaissmaier, W., Judgment and Decision Making
Rivals in the dark: How competition influences search in decisions under uncertainty | ND Phillips, R Hertwig, Y Kareev, J Avrahami | Cognition | |

title: Experience
text:
Open Source Projects
Most of my projects are proprietary, but here are some open source projects that I contribute to


FFTrees, A toolbox to create, visualize, and evaluate fast-and-frugal decision trees
yarrr, A package for creating pirate plots in R

title: Nathaniel D. Phillips, PhD
text:
I am a Data Scientist who loves helping people solve challenging problems and tell impact stories to technical and non-technical stakeholders.
I have experience across academia and industry building products and teams that generate insights from messy data.
I’m most well known for Healthcare Data Science, Open Source Data Science, and Decision Making Research.

title: Nathaniel D. Phillips, PhD
text:
Current Role
I am currently working as an independent consultant for healthcare data science. See Consulting to learn more

title: Nathaniel D. Phillips, PhD
text:
Education
I have a Bachelor’s degree in Mathematics from Grinnell College, A Master’s in Experimental Psychology at Ohio University, and a PhD in Experimental Psychology at the University of Basel.

title: Nathaniel D. Phillips, PhD
text:
Work history
I have a diverse work history as a developer, research scientist, and team lead across academia and industry. You can find a complete view of my working history at About https://www.linkedin.com/in/nathanieldphillips/.

title: Nathaniel D. Phillips, PhD
text:
Contact
You can email me at nathaniel.d.phillips.is@gmail.com or book a meeting with me at https://calendly.com/nathaniel-d-phillips.

title: Resources
text: Here are some of my favorite resources - a mixture of books, tutorials, blogs, podcasts and YouTube, and software.

title: Resources
text:
Books
Here are some of my favorite books

The Design of Everyday Things | Donald A. Norman | As applicable to programming as it is to the design of toilets|
The First 90 Days | Michael D. Watkins | A great resource for anyone starting a new job - recommended by Lura Long|
The Checklist Manifesto | Atul Gawande | Gawande is one of my favorite writers at the intersection of science and medicine. |
How big things get done | Bent Flyvbjerg, Dan Gardner | Should be required reading for anyone working on projects with teams - recommended by Nicole Mirea|
R for Data Science | Hadley Wickham, Garrett Grolemund | A great resource for learning R |
Writing R Packages | Hadley Wickham |The bible of R package development|

title: Resources
text:
Tutorials
Here are some of my favorite online tutorials and guides

Survival Analysis in R | Emily Zabor | A great introduction to survival analysis in R (by a fellow Grinnellian!)|

title: Resources
text:
Blogs
Here are some blogs I like by companies and people I admire

RStudio Blog | The RStudio blog is a great resource for learning about new features in RStudio and R.
Danielle Navarro | Danielle Navarro is a cognitive scientist who writes about statistics and programming in R. I was :this: close to joining Danielle for a Postdoc in Sydney back in 2016.|
Emily Riederer | Emily Riederer is a leading voice in modern data science|

title: Resources
text:
Podcasts and YouTube
Here are some of my favorite podcasts and YouTube channels

Cautionary Tales by Tim Harford | Wrong Tools Cost Lives|

title: Resources
text:
Software
Here are some of my favorite software tools

Notion | I use Notion for everything from project management to personal notes
RStudio | My favorite IDE for data science development
GitHub Copilot | Copilot is spectatular, especially using the RStudio Copilot Plugin
Quarto | The successor to my beloved RMarkdown which powers just about every document I create (including this website) |
